captions.text: ohohopllil asks
What is boy culture like in Korea and what's the ideal type?
Are they usually like the guys we see in dramas? We nasties really need to knooow~
So we asked SooZee about this
And she found a couple of interesting reading resources
First one was a survey taken by women about what their ideal type is in men
And the second one was a satirical blog post about exactly how picky girls can be
when it comes to meeting their ideal boyfriend.
Now obviously this is not going to be what Every Korean girl wants
Like SooZee does not agree with these things
But this is kind of like that overarching theme that girls might talk about with each other
Things that they are looking for in guys.
And there is also a lot of blind date culture in Korea
Or as it's called in Korean SoGaeTing
That's the Jamaican way of saying it...
It's more like sogaeting
Blind date. Hookups.
Sounds better than blind-date.
Sogaeting~
SoGae/SoGhei
Now there are some obvious characteristics when it comes to the ideal type that can be
understood pretty much universally.
Such as:
Having a buff body
Having great fashion sense
Have a cheerful and bright personality
Don't lose your temper and be polite
Has a charming smile
Be good at sex
Listens to what women say
Now if you ask me, I don't really know who would disagree with these
Like I'm not looking for a guy who has a buff body
I would like somebody who is rude and who doesn't listen to me.
I'm looking for someone with a creepy leer.
Like "Boy that was an excellent sex session since I'm so good at it"
"I'm going to put on my fashion clothing"
"Time for my charming smile"
Relationship over.
After that there are some characteristics that seem be specifically embedded in Korean culture
Not necessarily something that we're familial with ourselves
One of them, for example is
You having to graduate from one of the specific S.K.Y. Universities
That's Seoul University, Korea University or Yonsei University
Are you sure it's not Super Cookie Yummy?
Cookie starts with a "C"
Not all cookies [S]Seems like you failed that university
Now I don't know about you, but I have never really cared about what university somebody graduates from
and that wouldn't really be a fact that I'm looking for in a relationship
The thing that people may not realize about Korea is that
There are Tons of universities you can go to in Korea
Everywhere
But there are just the 3 that are most competitive
So pretty much if you don't go to one of these universities
You can't get a girlfriend ever
Well that's not true.
You are generalizing that.
You can't be someone's ideal type.
You want to know what the lowest form of University is in Korea
between dating culture?
Art School
SooZee didn't you go to Art School?
Yeay...
We love SooZee
[S]SooZee's great [M]You've got our love, SooZee
Another one of the requirements is that you have a job that earns you over 100mln Korean won in a year
which is roughly 100k dollars
And you have to be either a public government employee
Or you have to work for one of the major companies
Like Samsung or LG, or KIA or what not
So basically working for a well known brand
That kind of a company
The problem is is that these are really stressful to work at
You might be being paid well
You work INSANE hours
When are you going to have time to date somebody
If you're working up until midnight all of the time?
These companies require a lot of dedication
Some people live on campus
Like, we went to... Where did we go?
Was it LG that we went to?
And we saw that they have dorm life for people that work there.
You live at the factory you work in.
Another requirement is: you have to be 180cm or taller
Which pretty much means, that you will never date a K-pop idol except for maybe like 3 of them
Oh boy...
I'm sorry. Look, a lot of their profiles say that they're that tall
It's more like their ideal height but not their actual height.
Ok, listen. I have to say this.
I know that in North America a lot of girls want to date tall guys
It's kind of like a thing
I found that some of my students would rather date
I did like a survey with them
Right this was bizarre
We were talking about describing people's appearances
and that kind of stuff
And one of the things they talked about was...
They would rather date a tall good-looking guy who treats them really poorly
Than a short good-looking guy that treats them really well.
And I said to them like "NO!"
Like the self-esteem Martina came out and was like...
relationship satisfaction should me more important than how tall...
Another interesting requirement is:
The ideal guy should have studied for one year in another country.
It's usually an English-speaking country
To be more worldly, so you could speak other languages
But I heard, the key of it being 1 year is because you've been studying for a year
Not that you've been screwing around.
Because if you go... As we know from "Heirs", if you go overseas for more than a year
You'll start hanging around with crazy party people [S] who do nothing but drugs all of the time
Exactly. So one year is like that safety bubble of that "I didn't go there and shacked up with somebody
I went there to study. I came back. And I speak English"
Speaking of it, you need to have TOEIC score of at least 850
I don't actually know what 850 means, to be honest
Because I have never taken TOEIC
What's TOEIC? Teaching... Tomatoes... over... interesting  [S]Total... ovaries... interesting... English... Calculates
SooZee [S]SooZee, what does TOEIC mean?
TOEIC is a test... [S&M]No, what does it mean? TOEIC?
[SZ]Something something English...
SooZee failed!
SooZee did you take a TOEIC test?
I did. [M]What's your TOEIC score? [S]930?
SooZee is the ideal type. She has lived overseas
I just want to know how do you flirt with girls?
Would you be like: "Hey baby, check out my TOIEC. See that? Ooh you like that" [M]Give your charming smile. GO!
Ok, well now you just lost her.
870, you like that, don't you, girl?
And what's your height?
Well I'm 195cm. You like that girl? Oooh you like them numbers.
Question: can you drink 2 bottle of Soju?
Easily.
Do you enjoy drinking it, though?
Not at all.
Well then you're my ideal type, because apparently
If you drink at least 2 bottles of Soju and you're not intoxicated
eeeentoxicateeeed [Ref to Junsu's "Intoxication"]
But you don't really enjoy drinking
Then you're the ideal type.
Now some interesting stuff about Korean family life
Ideally you should an only child
Ideally your boyfriend's parents should live Outside the city
Who visit maybe once a year.
So that they aren't interfering with your life all too much.
I think that's an around the world thing.
I hope my in-laws live up stairs for me so that we can all visit each other and hold hands
There are a couple of things those we think are a lil bit WTF
I'm touching your butt right now. You guys can't see this, but...
Rule #3 you must be able to pat each other's butts
Speaking of which is actually really funny one
Which I think is a joke
Who is kind and bold enough to dance naked if the wife says so.
I don't know.. [S]DANCE MONKEY, DANCE!
If you're getting a K-pop idol I'm sure you would definitely do that all of the time
Rain does it anyways.
Give me your charming smile!
Now one of the negative thing that comes of having all these ideals is that a lot of Korean guys
Feel a lot of stress
Because a lot of these ideals are extremely unrealistic
With the pressure they have in society
And not only is it stressful for the guy regarding how much money they make
and the job that they have.
It seems like there wasn't a big emphasis on personality?
If they get along well.
Like: are they both artistic together?
Do they have the same interests?
It's more of a matter of how fundationally solid are you.
You can't really predict love in my opinion.
You might meet somebody who is a dinosaur who likes to dance [S]I'm doing my charming smile
It's a really charming smile~
But you know what I'm saying.
you don't know who you're going to meet.
What if you meet an art student that you totally fall in love with
and he is a sweet, awesome, amazing guy
Who wants to open up a coffee shop
and doesn't make that much money.
But you could be really happy for the rest of your lives.
You're going to turn that down just because some guy graduated from a better university?
I don't know... So what do you guys think about this list of ideal types?
Is it the same as things that are in your country?
Or are there ideal things in your country that are not on this list what so ever?
Let us know in the comment section below.
So that's it for this week's TL;DR
If you have a question for next TL;DR leave your question in the comment section below.
Or check out the questions already asked and you can thumb them up to bring them to our attention.
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs where we tell you how to date and fall in love~
I would not follow this advice to date and fall in love
This was a bad advice.
It's kind of more of an arranged marriage advice
It Does seem very arranged

comments.author: Seo Jae Im

comments.text:
I feel like some of the comments kind of miss a few things, but here's my 
take on it: I'm American. Now, your average American girl might really like 
a rich guy, a guy who's thin and works out a lot--nice abs, a decent trust 
fund, fast car, a good job, pretty smile, curly hair, dashing and daring, 
quick as a coursing river, etc etc.

Some of these things are general--like I'm totally cool with the pretty 
smile and curly hair, but the quick as a coursing river is entirely 
optional. Communication and an openness and willingness to share with me 
his thoughts and ideas are far more important. I feel like those things are 
unspoken but wanted ideals in any mate, for any person. For specifics for 
me, I'm very into the arty types who love books and as much as people mock 
hipsters, I'm totally cool with guys that can their own strawberry 
preserves and use beard oil.

I would say compatibility varies for a lot of people though, and in the 
long run and interest in each other and a willingness to work for that 
interest is the most important thing.

But yeah, when people say "korean women want so much." I'd say that out of 
a survey if 40 women say they want a guy who works for Samsung, LG, or 
Kia--then that goes on the list, meanwhile the 1-5 women who would totally 
date a coffee shop owner don't really get mentioned because it wasn't a top 
5 answer. Likewise, I assume women are answering the question based on an 
"ideal" fictional mate, which doesn't exist. Say you could "order up" the 
ideal spouse, what would s/he be?  The reality for myself is that after 
being very close to someone, the ideal spouse is someone who enjoys my 
company and makes passing the time a pleasant thing. For others, they never 
really experienced a relationship like this and mostly just think of things 
that would make their personal lives better(money, status) rather than the 
intangible things that require a lot of fancy work to express. So "He makes 
lots of money" is a natural answer for someone who believes that will lead 
to happiness.﻿

comments.author: Ai Quoc Nguyen

comments.text:
Personally, it's all about the experience than the expectations. Ok, so we 
do set some expectations but when we set the standards too high, you'll get 
disappointed in the end. I've gone through that (ended horribly) and 
seriously girls, don't expect too much because you'll never get anything in 
the end. We're all imperfect humans and there's a whole lot of limitations 
on us. And even if you really got them, ask yourself, will you really be 
happy with all that when your guy isn't?﻿
comments.author: D-Walker

comments.text:
I hope people thumbs up or at least make this aware. 
You must ask WHY there are these kinds of standards (university, height, 
double eyelids, etc) in Korea. I'd say that Koreans in general have a 
culture of flexing and showing off more so than North America in general. 
In fact, I've had some real encounters of korean people who go OUT OF THEIR 
WAY ( you wouldn't believe) to show their friends or parents about how well 
their lives are. Because relationships is part of your identity, of course 
these impersonal standards will prevail. Basically, korean girls don't want 
tall guys for themselves as much as wanting to SHOW OFF to THEIR 
girlfriends that they have a tall boyfriend.﻿

comments.text:
Most of the girls here in Bulgaria date older, richer dudes, so it's pretty 
much the same. Most of the time they don't even care about looks, they just 
want you to be financially stable and have a car (yeah, that legitimately 
matters :D). The phrase "daddy issues" doesn't really translate well in 
Bulgarian, but I've been praying for an equivalent so many times so I can 
say it directly in their faces. :D Again, MOST girls are like this, not all 
of them. I've met a lot of kind, sweet and amazing girls as well, but most 
of them.. are just gold diggers. ﻿

comments.author: Rui Liu

comments.text:
+Rui Liu I wasn't inquiring with bias initially. I was just asking for an 
opinion. I had doubts to whether what the user said was completely true 
since it DID indeed seem like a long shot.
Of course, I feel sympathy for the Korean guys who have difficulty 
overcoming these ideals in order to find someone. Although personal goals 
are important, you can't ignore the fact that the entire race will be 
extinct in a few hundred years or so. 
The more one is into work, the less they will have a personal life. Makes 
sense, because studies prove it; east asian countries have the highest 
academic readiness index, but the lowest level of happiness (conducted for 
students currently in high school)

I am not saying what they do is easy. I don't judge those who are living 
under the pressures of social influences. 
As a female majoring in computational sciences, and one of the only girls 
out of the several guys in all of my classes, I wouldn't mind sharing the 
sacrifices..

comments.author: Alex Davies

comments.text:
+fedfoofy Well this is definitely not true, in many cases around the world 
partners do not pick each other, let alone pick each other for their 
attractiveness or height etc. and even in cultures across the world where 
this is a factor let's face it the majority don't seek out people of 
specific sizes, and most people will have partners of many sizes and shapes 
due to the fact that the main pull of that partner was not their outward 
appearance, but rather their personality etc.

As for the western world being so set on ideals like these, I really have 
to disagree with you. Primarily because for instance that's a very accurate 
list of "what makes a perfect man" whereas polls over here show hugely 
varying ideas of an ideal partner in physical terms, height, shape, colour 
etc. etc. but that the ones that stay the same are generally what goes in 
in the mind, ie. Intelligence, a sense of humour, stepping in to help a 
woman etc.

Also not supporting your argument is the very open culture of desiring 
people who your views would suggest are unattractive and yet millions 
openly admit to, chubby chasers etc.

The truth is that in western cultures for quite a while and increasingly so 
now, things like those seem trivial in our cultures. We all may lust after 
somone because their bodies are very nice and admire that but it doesn't 
mean that it factors into your ideal partner.
comments.author: Alex Davies

comments.text:
+Alex Davies You're sadly naive if you think that the West is somehow any 
different from this. By the way, learn to take some things with a grain of 
salt. One video of some foreigner's opinions does not and could not 
accurately describe all of Korea. You act like people who don't go to SKY 
schools and/or are not considered attractive don't fall in love. What they 
described was obviously some *ideal* traits in a partner: attractiveness, 
intelligence, good education, financial stability. I'm just tired of seeing 
these comments of Westerners acting horrified that Koreans are "so so 
superficial," when humans are the same everywhere.
comments.author: fedfoofy

comments.text:
+fedfoofy To an extent, this does not need to be the bulk of what someone 
cares about. Nor the prime variables that determine someone's worth as a 
partner. What's up your ass?
comments.author: Alex Davies

comments.text:
+Alex Davies Oh shut the hell up. Stop living in a fairy tale ideal world. 
Everyone cares about money and looks. It's human nature, and there's 
nothing wrong with it.
comments.author: fedfoofy

comments.text:
To refute your claim on my hypocrisy, well, I do value ppl's opinion to a 
certain extent, You can definitely disagree but you don't necessarily have 
to call them disgusting cuz then things become aggressive and offensive, 
You can criticize the idea, but you insulted the people. Did the people who 
seeks wealth in their partners call you disgusting for having different 
thoughts? You're taking things so directly and hastily make criticism 
focusing on one premise of my comment, failing to see the main gist. My 
point was that you shouldn't hastily jump to conclusions especially when it 
comes to judging an ethnic group, and that making generalizations from a 
very small sample is foolish. I know you weren't exactly doing what I've 
described above, since I did notice you were calling ppl with those values 
disgusting, not Koreans. I was only trying to tell you that this is 
definitely not the accurate representation of Korean society and their 
values, since you were wondering about the credibility. I was quite upset 
at this video, since it is quite manipulative and could implant false 
images of Koreans into foreigners who are completely oblivious to this 
matter. I tried to oppose to your claim while not sounding rude at the same 
time, but I guess my words made you resentful. I apologize if that's the 
case, and I do accept your apology as well. 

I wasn't forcing my opinion on you or stopping you from freely expressing 
yours either. Seems as you've totally misunderstood my point. My emphasis 
was not on the valuing different ideas part... If you were busy not giving 
a fuck, why reply now? But oh well I do understand your resentment since 
you've completely misinterpreted my point.
comments.author: Kydouask

comments.text:
+Kydouask "I would value and respect your opinion if you had agreed with 
me" is what you should've said. If you're quite as genuine in your belief 
that everyone should be able to believe in whatever values they please then 
I'm quite entitled to my disgust, if they're allowed to express that 
opinion in the polls etc. quoted then I'm allowed to express mine. The 
truth is your whole statement is hypocritical.
See the difference is I recognize there's difference, and though I feel 
free to express my opinion of the other way of life I'm not trying to force 
my opinions on anyone or stop anyone else from expressing their opinions. 
You are.

I'm sorry for the late reply, was busy not giving a fuck
comments.author: Alex Davies

comments.text:
I would value and respect your opinion if you hadn't described the values 
discussed here as disgusting. Everyone has different values in life, and 
who are you to judge them? Plus, this is definitely not the accurate view 
of Korean society, although there are some instances where younger women 
may think this way, but as they mature, they stop looking for these 
criteria. I'm Korean and those are not the criteria I look for in men, but 
many of my friends from other ethnic groups often have values that you 
would call disgusting.

comments.text:
+Holler Yul :( Here in Holland we have elementary school where everyone is 
on the same grade but then middle school many different grades there are 3 
good ones and others are like school for people who don't really do 
anything for school or just aren't smart enough. but the 3 good grades are 
Vmbo-Havo-Vwo, If you got Vmbo it lasts 4 years and you can go MBO after 
wards which is 2-4 years depends on which side and grade you choose or you 
can do 2 more years Havo and then go to HBO which you can also go if you 
finished Havo which lasts 5 years and VWO lasts 6 years but if you finish 
in 6 years you can go uni at 18 y/o :( And at elementary school time i 
wasn't much into school and stuff i tought everything will come alright 
itself and i got Vmbo but first year i almost was allowed to go Havo but a 
teacher told lies about me >:c and now it feels like i'm climbing a 
mountain which has no top cause i'm doing a too easy grade for me. Thats 
why i wish i wasn't born here cause school has not enough discipline here.
